posts.cooked:
My team has a single jointed arm mechanism that is controlled by two TalonFX motors. I applied a sensorToMechansim ratio to both of them so that their value matches that of the systems (When the system does a rotation they show a rotation). The problem is that for one of them the positive direction is the opposite of what I want. When I spin the mechanism 1 rotation the correct motor will say that it spun 1 rotation but the incorrect motor will say that it spun -1 rotation. I tried inverting the motor but that did not change anything. I think that invert only affects motor output and not sensor readings. The thing that did work was setting the sensorToMechanism ratio of the motor to be negative. While this works I was wondering if this is the best practice or if there is a better way to do it.

I added below some basic code that summarizes what I am trying to do. Would the correct solution be to change the value of slavePolarity to -1 or is there a way to flip the sensor direction built into the TalonFX?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I haven’t done what you’re attempting to do, but “setting the sensor to mechanism ratio to be negative” is my first thought as to the most natural way to express that physical relationship. (In other words, I’d do exactly what you’ve done and feel like it was correct and natural.)

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: The setting you’re looking for is “sensor phase”. The built-in encoder is never out of phase, so it should never be inverted with respect to the motor. The CANcoder is the one that might need to be inverted such that a positive duty cycle output on the motor results in the CANCoder value increasing.

If I understand what you mean by sensor phase then the sensors are out of phase relative to each other. The positive direction for one is the negative direction for the other. This can be easily fixed for setting outputs by setting them inverted to one another, but there is no option to “flip” the direction of one of the sensor readings so that they will match.
Have you tested this go confirm? The sensor phase change should work

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: There is a setting to invert the CANCoder.
No there is no Cancoder in the system. It is only the two relative encoders of the motors.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Why not just make the slave a follower and ignore its reading entirely?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
The encoder built into the Talon FX should always be in phase with the motor. When you invert the motor, both its output and the sensor direction are inverted, that way positive motor output always results in a positive velocity reported by the encoder. So setting one motor to CounterClockwise_Positive (non-inverted) and the other to Clockwise_Positive (inverted) should fix the issue, provided that they’re currently both CounterClockwise_Positive when you see the issue.

Something to note, at least in the code snippet you sent, you are only setting the FeedbackConfigs group, which means all the configs in the other groups are left unchanged (i.e. not factory defaulted). If you want all the other configs to be factory defaulted, then you should instead create a TalonFXConfiguration object, modify its Feedback field (and whatever other configs you want to change), and apply the entire TalonFXConfiguration . Note that invert is a config in Phoenix 6.
